title: Podcast: The Worst Start to a Quarter Since 2008
text:
Three numbers to start your day:

It’s the worst start to a quarter since 2008. We all know what happened then.

Stocks sold off because investors continued to worry about September’s weaker-than-expected U.S. manufacturing data. On Tuesday, it showed the second straight month of a contraction in output.

But it’s too early to call a recession on the horizon. Manufacturing doesn’t mean as much to the U.S. economy as it once did. And job gains and consumer spending remain high.

The World Trade Organization Ruled That The U.S. Can Tax $7.5 Billion

—worth of exports from Europe. Why? The European Union has provided subsidies to the airplane manufacturer Airbus (EADSY) for years. The international trade body, the WTO, found that practice unfair and says that the U.S. can retaliate.

The ruling covers only 1% of total trade between the U.S. and Europe. But some investors worried that U.S. tariffs could be met with retaliation. The last thing that already-struggling manufacturers need is another trade war.

Delta Air Lines Stock Fell 4.7% on Wednesday

The decline came after the company warned investors of increasing costs in an update on its third-quarter performance.

That came as a surprise—Delta stock (DAL) has outperformed other airlines this year. It’s had strong earnings and doesn’t fly any of Boeing ’s grounded 737 Max aircraft. It’s also expanded its Latin America business and raised its dividend.

But now management sees employee wages and maintenance costs set to rise. That means tighter margins and lower profit growth next year.

Numbers by Barron’s is our daily podcast. Find out more here.

description: A WTO ruling could be a first step in a new trade war with Europe. Delta Air Lines stock drops as the company announces increased costs. And why it’s too early to call a recession on the horizon.
